results.title: Jedda [DVD]
results.creator_credit: Charles Chauvel and Charles Chauvel Productions
results.brief_description:
As Australia’s first feature film with Aboriginal lead roles, Jedda is beloved by many First Peoples. It was one of the first times we saw stories of our people explored and it’s lauded for its representation of “so many Aboriginal men and women, girls and boys on the screen.” But despite being a first for First Peoples representation, Jedda also reflects a deeply problematic time in Australian history characterised by formal policies of assimilation and the forced removal of Indigenous children from their families by the government.
The tale of an Aboriginal woman torn between her white upbringing and her heritage, Jedda (Charles Chauvel’s last feature film) is the first Australian-made colour feature and first Australian film nominated for the Cannes Film Festival’s Palme d’Or. It stars Arrernte actress Rosalie Kunoth-Monks (credited as Ngarla Kunoth) as Jedda and Tiwi actor Robert Tudawali as Marbuck. Due to the film’s popularity, and a rising interest in Aboriginal ‘kitsch’ and culture, Kunoth-Monks and Jedda became entwined. But unlike Tudawali, who had other roles, Kunoth-Monks never acted again and became an advocate for Australia’s First Peoples. Cast also includes Betty Suttor, Paul Reynall, George Simpson-Lytle, Tas Fitzer, Wason Byers, Willie Farrar, and Margaret Dingle

results.title: Terminal velocity
results.creator_credit: Deran Sarafian, Scott Kroopf, Tom Engelman, Buena Vista and Hollywood Pictures
results.brief_description: All is not what it seems in this action thriller starring Charlie Sheen as the hard-playing reckless skydiving teacher, Ditch Brodie, who finds himself asking questions when his beautiful new student Chris Morrow (Nastassja Kinski) mysteriously meets with a tragic accident on her first jump. Suspense and intrigue follow as Brodie accused of manslaughter is caught up in international espionage involving the Russian mafia. Cast includes James Gandolfini, Chris McDonald.

results.title: The Book of life
results.creator_credit: Hal Hartley, Matt Myers, Thierry Cagianut, Arte, Haut et Court and La Sept
results.brief_description: In the late 1990s a French production company invited several directors to make a short feature about the last day of the millennium; Hal Hartley (the only American to be asked) created a film about Jesus Christ descending to earth to unleash a series of plagues that will end humanity. He is accompanied on this journey by Mary Magdalene (played by English rock icon PJ Harvey) and is forced to face the devil (Thomas Jay Ryan) who has also arrived in New York seeking a showdown with his nemesis. As Jesus retrieves the book (which, in a clever update, is a notebook computer) the devil sits in a bar discussing the merits of humanity with a barmaid and a compulsive gambler. Hartley utilises an array of video and digital techniques, blurring the visuals, speeding them up, slowing them down which creates an effective sense of disorientation and doom. Hartley mainstay Martin Donovan is typically diffident in the role of Jesus.

results.title: The Chinese girl = La Chinoise
results.creator_credit: Jean-Luc Godard, Anouchka Films, De La Gueville and Parc Film
results.brief_description: This experimental non-linear work, about five students who embrace Maoism, heralded the second wave of Godard’s filmmaking - The Revolutionary. Spending the summer in the bourgeois surrounds of a borrowed flat, the students become immersed in the doctrine of Chairman Mao’s Little Red Book, discussing methodologies (which include terrorism and assassination) to overthrow governmental systems. Heralded by some as groundbreaking cinema that subverted popular notions of filmmaking (recall Godard’s famous quote: “A story should have a beginning, a middle and an end, but not necessarily in that order”), “La Chinoise” also confounded many Godard admirers with its obscure polemic. Cast includes: Juliet Berto, Jean-Pierre Leaud, Anne Wiazemsky and Blandine Jeanson.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Jean-Luc Godard, Anouchka Films, De La Gueville and Parc Film

results.title: Scandal = Shuban
results.brief_description: Made before Kurosawa’s breakthrough film “Rashomon”, “Scandal” is about a young painter, Ichiro, who finds himself embroiled in a scandal, when, whilst holidaying, he offers a motorbike ride to a famous singer. When two paparazzi witness this innocent outing they transform the incident into a torrid affair between the two. Outraged, Ichiro decides to sue, but the lawyer he employs - himself in a compromised situation - is easily bribed. A morality tale about the freedom of the press versus the rights of the individual, Kurosawa addresses the Americanisation of post-war Japan with his melodramatic screenplay, co-written with Ryuzo Kikushima. Beautiful black and white cinematography and impressive performances by Yoshiko Yamaguchi and Takashi Shimura.

results.title: Red Beard = Akahige
results.creator_credit: Akira Kurosawa and Toho Kabushiki Kaisha
results.brief_description: The last collaboration between actor Toshiro Mifune and Kurosawa, is a moral tale about a young and arrogant medical graduate - charged by his modern training and ambition - who is devastated to be assigned to an impoverished local clinic. The young doctor’s mentor, Red Beard, aims to show the young gun that there is more to life than prestige and power and more to healing than medicine. Set in 1820, this is a poignant and compassionate work; a humanistic narrative that follows the character’s arc from supercilious to empathetic whilst presenting a myriad of stories about the villagers and their struggles.

results.title: Power and terror: Noam Chomsky in our times
results.brief_description: A series of lectures by eminent American expert on foreign policy, Noam Chomsky, are centred around the issues of September 11 - the United States’ response to the disaster, as well as the Government’s participation in terrorism. Chomsky displays his signature articulation and intelligence in these illuminating pieces, providing a complex picture of world politics. He deftly places the terrorist attacks in the context of American foreign intervention throughout the decades: for example in Vietnam, Central America and the Middle East. In stark and uncompromising terms Chomsky presents his views that challenge widely held perceptions about America’s motivations, in a refreshingly composed and astute way. Some lectures include question and answer forums with the audience.

results.title: The Corporation
results.creator_credit: Jennifer Abbott, Mark Achbar, Bart Simpson and Big Picture Media Corporation
results.brief_description: Entertaining, illuminating and exhaustively researched Canadian documentary about the rise in power and stature of corporations, and the impact felt throughout the world. Many topics are examined over the course of this work including exploitation of developing countries, company fraud, environmental impact of business on the natural world, business ethics, corporate espionage, media power, censorship, globalisation, marketing manipulation, privatisation and protests. Featuring a wide array of interviews, witty graphics and a soothing voice-over, the filmmakers succeed in making the complexities of the issues at play here understood whilst enrapturing the audience. Winner of the Best Documentary World Cinema Audience Award at the 2004 Sundance Film Festival. Interviewees include: Naomi Klein, Michael Moore and Noam Chomsky.

results.title: Springtime in a small town = Xiao cheng zhi chun
results.creator_credit: Tian Zhuangzhuang, Bill Kong, Li Xiaowan, Ting Yatming, Beijing Film Studio and China Film Group Corporation
results.brief_description: Finely crafted romantic drama about a young married woman who dutifully cares for her sickly husband, but whose feelings for a former beau reawakens her desire. Set amid the post-WW2 ruins of a small town, this film exquisitely portrays Yuwens longing, which contrasts with her efficient but cold care of her ailing and ill-tempered husband. Director Tian Zhuangzuang (The Blue kite), part of the fifth generation of Chinese filmmakers observes his protagonists through doorways and windows, providing an apt metaphor for their inability to connect. A film that allows the tension to build in a languid but effective manner, as the three angst ridden players make their choices. Cast includes Hu Jingfan, Wu Jun, Xin Baiqing, Ye Xiaokeng and Lu Sisi.

results.title: Amandla! A revolution in four-part harmony
results.creator_credit: Lee Hirsch, Desiree Markgraaf, Sherry Simpson, Bomb, Cinemax Reel Life, Ford Foundation, Kwela Productions and South African Broadcasting Corporation
results.brief_description: Celebratory, but also poignant, documentary about the history of South African apartheid, as seen through the eyes of numerous black South African musicians and artists. Interviews are interwoven with footage from the 1940s and beyond — footage that portrays the awful discrimination and brutality of apartheid. Activists used music to express their rage and frustration at the ruling government, often incurring the wrath of the oppressive regime with their protest songs. The dissenters used these songs to mobilise the masses while venting their sorrow at the injustices being suffered. These artists argue convincingly that the songs were integral to the struggle, providing an inestimable tole in the victory over apartheid. Performers and interviewees include: Thandi Modise, Vusi Mahlasela, Sibongile Khumalo, Duma KaNdlovu, Sibusiso Nxumalo, Lindiwe Zulu, Miriam Makeba, Abdullah Ibrahim, Sifiso Ntuli, Dolly Rathebe, and Hugh Masekela.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Lee Hirsch, Desiree Markgraaf, Sherry Simpson, Bomb, Cinemax Reel Life, Ford Foundation, Kwela Productions and South African Broadcasting Corporation

Interviews are interwoven with footage from the 1940s and beyond — footage that portrays the awful discrimination and brutality of apartheid. Activists used music to express their rage and frustration at the ruling government, often incurring the wrath of the oppressive regime with their protest songs. The dissenters used these songs to mobilise the masses while venting their sorrow at the injustices being suffered. These artists argue convincingly that the songs were integral to the struggle, providing an inestimable tole in the victory over apartheid. Performers and interviewees include: Thandi Modise, Vusi Mahlasela, Sibongile Khumalo, Duma KaNdlovu, Sibusiso Nxumalo, Lindiwe Zulu, Miriam Makeba, Abdullah Ibrahim, Sifiso Ntuli, Dolly Rathebe, and Hugh Masekela.
description_for_label: Celebratory, but also poignant, documentary about the history of South African apartheid, as seen through the eyes of numerous black South African musicians and artists. Interviews are interwoven with footage from the 1940s and beyond — footage that portrays the awful discrimination and brutality of apartheid. Activists used music to express their rage and frustration at the ruling government, often incurring the wrath of the oppressive regime with their protest songs. The dissenters used these songs to mobilise the masses while venting their sorrow at the injustices being suffered. These artists argue convincingly that the songs were integral to the struggle, providing an inestimable tole in the victory over apartheid. Performers and interviewees include: Thandi Modise, Vusi Mahlasela, Sibongile Khumalo, Duma KaNdlovu, Sibusiso Nxumalo, Lindiwe Zulu, Miriam Makeba, Abdullah Ibrahim, Sifiso Ntuli, Dolly Rathebe, and Hugh Masekela.
